utterances: Yes.
Yes.
And that's the difference.
Nor did anyone emphasize wealth...
Exactly.
No, that's what I said.
...as an outcome.
Exactly.
The outcome that we were taught to achieve was excellence.
Wealth was not...
Never.
...even a predicted outcome.
It was fine if you managed to get something.
Exactly.
But wealth was not the focus and...
But it wasn't begrudging wealth.
No.
No, no. Oh, no, no, not at all.
No, it wasn't even an issue.
It wasn't even an issue.
It wasn't even an issue.
We knew...
But now it's...
Yeah, exactly.
...get rich or die trying.
And quick.
And quick, yes.
I can't even remember the people we considered wealthy.
We knew that morticians had independence, but quite frankly, beauticians and barbers...
And barbers, absolutely.
...were respected because they were not working for, quote, ""the white man""...
Exactly.
...and they had great independence, great names.
So we didn't look up to people because they had belongings.
We looked up to those who had the intellect.
Oh, absolutely.
I was mesmerized whenever I heard these leaders talk.
So--and my teachers were constantly saying to me, `No, you can do this.
You can do that.
So I never feared.
One of the major differences in leadership today and in the past, I think we had more ethical leadership.
Now most people are in it, it's about for themselves or it comes across that way, whereas I think with poor people, it was about the common good.
You know, you looked at--not that people didn't get and did not gain but it was, like, more people tend to move than now you see one or two moving, but more people.

When you look at the bus boycott, I think, you know, we're talking about ethical decision-making where it wasn't just about me getting a seat in the front of the bus but about all of us being able to sit there.
And I think that more of the thinking was more about more of us doing it than just one or two of them out of the group being able to move.

As you sit today in 2005 and we celebrate the 50th anniversary, I'm curious to hear from each one of you the idea of where the expectation was of where you thought we would be and where we actually find ourselves.
Did it meet your expectation?
I have to be honest and say that I could not have told you or predicted in 1965 when I graduated from Lamb High(ph) that we would be in 2005 where we are now.
As a child with an immature self view and immature--and I don't mean that critically.
I just mean it factually--with an immature expectation of what I would become, I fully expected to lead my parents' lifestyle.
I knew that in '65 things were slightly better than they were in '54, but I did not predict the fullness of physical integration as we know it today.
I did predict increasing and consistently increasing opportunity for African-Americans.
I'm the product of a desegregated South.
There was no integration when I left, none.
So this is very different.
There's no way I could have looked at it and said that things were going to be changed at all.

And in terms of looking at the 50th, where we are now in Montgomery, I must say that in terms of what we've done, the kinds of things that we're doing to celebrate did not surprise me at all in terms of the way things have come down, and I say that because we have not done the kinds of things, we have not done the work that would say that we are a cohesive unit.
That takes time.
I look at it this way.
When you start talking about--everybody uses that word reconciliation and it's time to reconcile and people need to just get on with it, this will be OK, it doesn't work that way.
You have to go through the motions.
Many people in Montgomery are in avoidance.
They don't want to deal with it.
These were ugly times.
They were hard times.
They were mean.
They were cruel, painful to a lot of people on a lot of sides.
They don't want to relive that.
Others are in just denial that it ever happened at all, that any of that was going on.
Some--or at the blame game, it was, `You did it.
You did this to me.
How did you do this?
Others are just enraged.
What we have not done is accepted that it is a part of our history, it did happen.
Delores, let me take you slightly different in terms of the question I have.
Let's fast forward 25 years.
And now we're at the 25th anniversary and you're looking at where you are.
Stop there and now fast forward today, 25 years later.
Are we where you would have imagined or did the train slow?
The train clearly slowed.
I left in '68 after high school.
I returned in '75 after law school.
With pleasure, I returned to find more black lawyers than were here when I left.
I'd not seen a black woman lawyer when I left.
There were none.
In fact, I believe my group started that first cavalcade of lawyers.
So I returned to a city with more opportunity as Van said, whether economically or politically, but I returned to a city still pretty much in separate camps.
Let me ask you all this as a closing question.
Why am I able to find the three of you still here and able to sit together?
Obviously, you would have had the opportunity, the means, the chance to go elsewhere.
More coming up on DAY TO DAY on NPR News.
Yeah, I get the concern, and I think the bottom-line solution is that you've got to have transparency.
Right.
My reason for being a lawyer is attributable to the civil rights movement.
Thus, it was absolutely imperative for me to succeed in my hometown.
I wanted to come back and provide legal services to the people who did not have it.
So I was on a mission.
I still am on a mission.
My family's here, the extended family which supported me.
I'm here because the need is here and I'm still a child of the '60s who believes that my duty, my role, my mission is to go beyond me.
Surely, I could go elsewhere and have gone elsewhere, but I've come back here to make a difference in the town which nurtured me.
I came back in 1975 from New York City, and I did work on Wall Street for a year.
I found it nourishing and enlightening but I think that was due more than anything else to the fact that it was my first year of practice.
I'm confident that I wouldn't have found it so in the ninth and 10th year.
I came back here because of the challenges.
Family and the South--I simply prefer living in the South.
My family, of course, lured me here, but like Delores, there was work to be done here.
I'm proud to say that I did some of that work before joining the bench.

I feel like I did a better job of doing that job before the bench quite frankly than since I joined the bench almost 14 years ago, but there have been so many things that we've been able to do and I feel we were taught to make a difference.
We were taught that you were worthless if you have not made a difference.
So I believe that it is here that we had the greatest opportunity to make that difference.
I'm still convinced of that.

Again, I came back because my family again lured me back, but it was important for me once I decided to stay here was to give back to a community that had given me so much and also to look at I had things to offer and why give?
Oftentimes, people that give you everything never really benefit from what you've become.
So my thing was to come back and to kind of get some of that nurture and some of what I've learned elsewhere.
I came back from the Virgin Islands having lived there almost 15 years.
I was gone about 23 before I returned and I wanted to give to my community some of what the world--that they started and the world had given me.
Georgette Norman is the director of the Rosa Parks Library and Museum at Troy State University in Montgomery, Alabama.
Vanzetta Penn McPherson and Delores Boyd are both US magistrate judges for the Middle District of Alabama.
You're listening to NEWS & NOTES from NPR News.
This is Talk of the Nation.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.

There are reports of record turnouts in states with early voting and complaints of long lines, seemingly endless waits, and already both political parties charge the other side plans to steal the election.
Democrats level accusations of systematic efforts to purge voting rolls, suppress turnout and disqualify illegal voters.
Republicans charge that record numbers of new voter registrations include large numbers of frauds.
So after the dangling chads and butterfly ballots eight years ago and the problems with provisional ballots and new machines four years ago, can we trust the election of 2008?
What do you see where you live?
What's your biggest concern come voting day?

You can also join our conversation on our blog, that's at npr.org/blogofthenation.
Later in the program, legend has it that hemlines rise and fall with the economy - down in bad years, up when times are good.
Email us your personal economic index.
The address is talk@npr.org.
But first, can we trust this election?
And we begin with Daniel Tokaji.
He's an associate professor at Moritz College of Law at the Ohio State University.

He's served as counsel for groups from both parties that have filed friend-of-the-court briefs in several of the cases in this election season and joins us now from the studios at Ohio State University in Columbus.
Nice to have you on the program today.
Well, thank you so much for having me.
And let's start with the allegations of purging.
First of all, what is it and how widespread is it?
